metadata.case_name: Descendant of Ganpati Maharaj v. Descendants of Nagubai

facts.text: Ganpati Maharaj died in 1701 at age 98. At age 72, he had a dream revealing an image of Venkatesh Balaji in river Tambraparni, which he found, brought to Junnar (Poona District), and installed in his house.
Ganpati Maharaj left three sons and a daughter. Eldest son Timmayya, aged 12 at father's death, succeeded and lived till 1768 (age 79), acquiring properties as presents and gifts during his lifetime.

Deity moved from Junnar to Nasik in Timmayya's lifetime due to a dream warning of Junnar burning. Timmayya acquainted locality with deity's powers, took it to rulers' courts, acquiring properties, cash allowances, gifts.

After Timmayya's death, eldest son Bapaji Buva obtained land gift from Peshwa near Godavari at Nasik, built temple, installed deity. Raised loan for construction, partly paid by Peshwa, Holkar, Scindia. Built Sabha Mandap for 600 persons.

Family disputes in 1774 led to Tahanama (Ex.121): management vested in eldest male of senior branch; provision for maintenance of branches; villages granted for Seva of Shri; temple belongs to Sansthan, no shares; sum for Seva not to diminish; small Nemnuk for maintenance.
Further disputes in 1800 led to Tharav Yadi (Ex.122): villages assigned for maintenance instead of cash; Nemnuk described as Vetan (remuneration) for service to deity.

Inam Commission under Bombay Rent-free Estates Act, 1852: Assistant Commissioner recorded villages as personal inams (R.3 Sch.B). Damodar Maharaj appealed, contended Devasthan inams (R.7 Sch.B, permanent). Commissioner accepted, changed entries to Devasthan inams.
Damodar Maharaj died 1885, succeeded by Krishnarao (d.1893), then Bhagwantrao (d.1900), then appellant (minority till 1921, guardian managed).
Appellant published history of deity in 1929 (Ex.642, 1931 edition): sansthan belongs to deity, family are managers.

Respondents 1-4 (descendants from Ganpati's daughter Nagubai) applied to District Court on April 23, 1942 under s.3 Charitable and Religious Trusts Act 1920 against appellant and others for particulars of properties, accounts.

Appellant denied public trust, claimed private; undertook to file suit under s.53 Act. Filed suit March 21, 1943: declarations that no legal trust, or if any not public/charitable, Act inapplicable; defendants/Hindu community no right/authority.

Trial Judge (Civil Judge Senior Division Nasik, Special Suit No.5/1943) decided Aug 14, 1945: properties not private; estoppel; deity not family; public religious charitable trust; appellant hereditary shebait; defendants 1-4 entitled to customary worship/emoluments; suit bad without deity; dismissed suit, two sets costs.
Public notice under O.1 R.8 CPC issued, other defendants joined representing Hindu community.
Defendants sought to join deity as party; appellant opposed; trial judge warned suit might fail without deity, but did not join.

High Court Bombay (Rajadhyaksha and Chainani JJ) First Appeal 403/1945, April 22, 1949: dismissed appeal, some properties likely personal but no declaration without deity; modified to one set costs; certificate under Art.133 Constitution.

Numerous admissions by appellant/predecessors: properties Devasthan inams, belong to Sansthan/deity, family managers/servants (e.g., Tahanama 1774, Tharav 1800, Inam appeals 1858 Ex.D-643, depositions 1899,1907,1920,1927, history Ex.642).

Public worship: temple open 7am-10pm, no exclusion except one family incident; merchants kangi; daily feeding Brahmans/others; Utsavs, processions 10 days 10 carriages; Rajopchar; collection box; Gazetteer describes public.
Temple: staircase to idol, Sabha Mandap 600 persons, several acres; family resides in portions but distinct from temple.
Deity movable (chala), temporarily removed for processions/invitations, substitute left; custom 250+ years, no objection.
Properties: 11 villages (Inam Commission Devasthan), cash allowances, urban (e.g., Balaji temple land grant for temple Ex.571, Shree Theatre). No separate accounts.

legal_issues.text: Whether Shri Venkatesh Balaji Deity and Sansthan constitute a legal public religious and charitable trust to which Charitable and Religious Trusts Act 1920 applies, or private/family deity and properties.
Whether defendants/Hindu community have right/authority over deity/Sansthan, to seek properties list/accounts.
Whether suit bad for non-joinder of deity.
Burden of proof under s.53 Act.
Nature of specific properties (e.g., some inclined personal by High Court).
Public right of worship in temple/deity.

petitioner_arguments.text: No trust exists, or if any, private/family not public/charitable; Act inapplicable; properties private personal of appellant as direct descendant eldest line.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.53 Charitable and Religious Trusts Act 1920; burden on respondents

petitioner_arguments.text: Documents misconstrued; grants to individuals/managers for family deity service; admissions erroneous/not binding; Inam decisions not conclusive.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Babu Bhagwan Din v. Gir Har Saroop (1939) LR 67 IA 1

petitioner_arguments.text: Deity private: no dome/Kalas, upper floor, family residence, movable, worship suspended births/deaths, invited private homes.
Some properties private (jat inams, Balaji temple land, Shree Theatre, Kulkarni); declare so; join deity now.
No need join deity as suit claims private ownership.

respondent_arguments.text: Public religious charitable trust; properties Devasthan endowments; appellant hereditary shebait/manager only.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.3 Charitable and Religious Trusts Act 1920

respondent_arguments.text: Admissions by appellant/predecessors from 1774 confirm Devasthan ownership; revenue records; public user/worship.
Deity necessary party; suit bad without.

court_reasoning.text: Findings of lower courts concurrent on public trust: not mere fact but legal inference from documents/admissions; no misconstruction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Admissions best evidence, repeated 1774-1931; family servants, deity owner.

court_reasoning.text: Burden academic: both led evidence; admissions shift burden to appellant to disprove, failed; suppressed original sanads.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inam Commission decisions high value as act of State.

court_reasoning.text: Documents (Tahanama, Tharav, Inam appeals) show deity owner, family Vetan/servants; not private division.
Villages/cash: Inam uniform Devasthan; produced letters not originals; respondents showed some for Shri expenses.
Public temple: open access, feeding, Utsavs, processions, grants by rulers, vast structure, 200yr user as right; Gazetteer/history.
Movable chala pratishta allows temporary removal; custom antiquity/public consent; cases permit temporary/permanent if necessary/consent.
No declaration on specific properties: non-joinder deity; no distinction pleaded; no separate accounts; trustee burden heavy.
No need decide individual rights (worship/maintenance): suit under s.53 only nature of trust.

holdings.text: Shri Venkatesh Balaji Deity/Sansthan public religious charitable trust; properties endowments owned by deity; appellant hereditary shebait/manager.
Suit rightly dismissed for non-joinder deity; no declarations esp. specific properties.

precedents_cited.case_name: Arunachellam Chetty v. Venkatachellapathi Guru Swamigal
precedents_cited.relevance: Utmost importance to Inam Registers as act of State, history/tenure.

precedents_cited.case_name: Babu Bhagwan Din v. Gir Har Saroop
precedents_cited.relevance: Single perpetual grant to individual/heirs not endowment; inapplicable here.
Heavy onus on trustee to prove personal acquisition legitimate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narayanan v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board
precedents_cited.relevance: Inference of public from user/institution; long user presumes as of right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pramatha Nath Mullick v. Pradyumna Kumar Mullick
precedents_cited.relevance: Idol's will via representative for location; too late to join now.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Soondur Thakoor v. Taruck Chunder Turkoruttun

precedents_cited.relevance: No permanent removal without necessity despite dilapidation.
Worshippers may remove to new site if ruins/insanitary.

statutes_cited.name: Charitable and Religious Trusts Act, 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: Application for particulars/accounts; suit to deny public trust.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Rent-free Estates Act, 1852
statutes_cited.relevance: Personal vs Devasthan inams; permanent recording.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed confirming lower courts: suit seeking declarations of private ownership rightly dismissed as properties/deity/Sansthan form public religious charitable trust owned by deity; no declarations on specific properties or individual rights due to non-joinder and scope.
outcome.costs: Appellant to pay costs of Respondent 1 personally; High Court modified to one set.

key_quotes.text: "The reader of the present history will have observed that the sansthan belongs to the deity and the members of the house of Timaya Maharaj are merely the managers and administrators of the same"
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner
key_quotes.significance: Admission in appellant-published history (Ex.642) confirming public trust.

key_quotes.text: "An admission is the best evidence that an opposing party can rely upon, and though not conclusive, is decisive of the matter, unless successfully withdrawn or proved erroneous."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains weight of repeated admissions shifting burden.

key_quotes.text: "The onus is heavily upon the trustee to show by the clearest and most unimpeachable evidence the legitimacy of his personal acquisition."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Citing Srinivasa Chariar on trustee's heavy burden.

key_quotes.text: "once a long course of user by the public for the purpose of worship is established... it is fair to infer that the institution must have been dedicated for user by the public."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for public temple from Narayanan case.
